content.title: Venous Malformations

definition.primary: Slow-flow vascular malformations composed of abnormal, ectatic venous channels lined by flat endothelium, present at birth but often becoming clinically apparent later in life, characterized by blue discoloration, compressibility, and phleboliths.
key_concepts: Most common type of vascular malformation (2:1 over AVMs)
Present at birth, grow proportionally with child, may expand with puberty/pregnancy
ISSVA classification: simple vascular malformations, slow-flow type

simple_vs_combined: Combined: VM with other malformation types (e.g., capillary-venous)

genetic_subtypes.type: Multifocal VM/Blue rubber bleb nevus syndrome

molecular.effect: Abnormal endothelial cell function, impaired smooth muscle recruitment
molecular.result: Dilated, irregular venous channels with deficient smooth muscle wall

appearance.change_with_position: Enlarge with dependency, deflate with elevation

symptoms.pattern: May be episodic with thrombosis episodes

complications: Localized intravascular coagulopathy (LIC) - elevated D-dimer, low fibrinogen

clinical_features: Present since birth (may not be noticed initially)

imaging.findings: Compressible, low-flow or no-flow on Doppler, phleboliths with shadowing

imaging.utility: Performed during sclerotherapy to assess extent and drainage

laboratory.fibrinogen: May be low in extensive lesions

compression.benefit: Reduces swelling, pain, may slow progression

conservative.analgesia: NSAIDs for pain, especially during thrombosis episodes

anticoagulation.indication: LIC with low fibrinogen, perioperative prophylaxis

agents.risks: Higher complication rate (nerve injury, skin necrosis)

principles: Consider staged approach for large lesions
High recurrence risk with incomplete excision

sirolimus.evidence: Case series showing benefit in extensive, refractory VM

prognosis.natural_history: Slow progression throughout life, may accelerate with hormonal changes
prognosis.treatment_outcomes: Symptomatic improvement achievable in most; cure rare for extensive lesions

learning_objectives: Classify venous malformations using ISSVA terminology
Recognize clinical features distinguishing VM from other vascular anomalies
Select appropriate imaging modalities for diagnosis
Understand the role of sclerotherapy as first-line treatment
key_points: Venous malformations are low-flow lesions present from birth
MRI is gold standard - high T2 signal, no flow voids, phleboliths
Sclerotherapy is first-line treatment for most symptomatic VMs
Check D-dimer/fibrinogen before procedures in extensive lesions
Complete cure is rare - treatment is for symptom control
clinical_pearls: Blue, compressible mass that enlarges with Valsalva = VM until proven otherwise
Elevated D-dimer is expected - don't reflexively anticoagulate
Multiple treatment sessions are the rule, not the exception

references.evidence_basis: ISSVA classification, consensus guidelines, case series
